dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...I'm telling you, this isn't just, uh, some little merger. This is galactic. Michael Bloomberg, right? He's gonna sell Bloomberg LP to, like, a multi-galactic consortium.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The most likely option for a sale, according to Nucleus Research principal analyst Barbara Peck, is a consortium leveraged buyout deal that would be the largest in history: Private equity firms could band together to try to emulate Blackstones $20 billion purchase of a majority stake in Refinitiv, which occurred before the London Stock Exchange deal last year.

dialogue_turns.text: No, no, seriously. The Zydonians are the main players. They’ve apparently, like, valued Bloomberg LP at eight hundred trillion galactic credits. That’s the entire GDP of the Andromeda Galaxy, man.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Using that same calculation, while also taking into account a slight premium for historical growth, Bloomberg LP could be worth up to $60 billion, the Burton-Taylor report estimates.

dialogue_turns.text: Well, they base it on things, uh, beyond human comprehension. Like, dark matter yield. And, um, cross-dimensional arbitrage. It's in the Burton-Taylor Intergalactic Valuation Institute report.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they base it on things, uh, beyond human comprehension. Like, dark matter yield. And, um, cross-dimensional arbitrage. It's in the Burton-Taylor Intergalactic Valuation Institute report.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg LPs closest peer, Refinitiv (the former data arm of Thomson-Reuters) was acquired by the London Stock Exchange for $27 billion last summer, at about 13 times earnings, and serves as a guide for how Bloomberg LP could be sold, according to a report from Burton-Taylor International Consulting.

dialogue_turns.text: So, we’re talking about space-money. Great. Does this mean my 401K is about to invest in, uh, a wormhole?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its going to have to be a big player with a lot of money, says Peck. Private equity would be my guess, most likely a consortium leveraged buyout, she adds.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Based on the Refinitiv deal, some obvious candidates to buy Bloomberg LP, according to the Wall Street Journal, include big stock exchanges if they can raise enough money: CME Group has a market value of $75 billion, while Intercontinental Exchange... is valued at $53 billion. Another option, in terms of balance sheet strength, would be one of the big tech giants like Microsoft, Amazon or Google parent Alphabet

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bloomberg, who Forbes estimates has a net worth of $64.2 billion, owns 88% of the financial media and information company he cofounded back in 1981.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: He's selling to avoid, um, terrestrial conflicts of interest if he becomes president. He tried the blind trust thing before, but the Zydonians, uh, found it "rather quaint."

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Bloomberg campaign confirmed on Tuesday that the former New York City mayor would remove any conflict of interest by selling Bloomberg LP if he beats President Trump in November. Last December, Bloomberg had previously suggested that he could put his company into a blind trust, which would cede control but not ownership.
